snippet: Nicotine replacements have no lasting benefit in helping smokers quit and may backfire, according to the most rigorous long-term study to date.
abstract: Harvard University study published in journal Tobacco Control shows that the nicotine gum and patches used by millions to help them stop smoking have no lasting benefit and may backfire in some cases: study is likely to inflame a long-running debate about the value of nicotine alternatives, an industry with a market that rose to more than $800 million annually in 2007 and whose products are covered by Medicaid in many states.
lead_paragraph: Nicotine replacements have no lasting benefit in helping smokers quit and may backfire, according to the most rigorous long-term study to date.

headline.seo: Nicotine Replacement Doesn’t Help Smokers Quit, Study Finds
headline.main: Nicotine Gum and Skin Patch Face New Doubt
headline.print_headline: Nicotine Gum And Skin Patch Face New Doubt
